bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 27, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison attempts to clear up the confusion about the number of photographs requested by Hench. He informs him that the autographed photographs by Moran and Kissinger still cannot be located.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, November 27, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
November 27, 1940

div1.p:
On receiving your letter I checked with
Mr. Brewer on the various questions raised.

So far as we can discover, there was no
picture taken of me presenting you with the degree.
It is a shame we did not set that up and have it taken
that day some time later than the exercises.

In regard to the photographs sent, I think
Mr. Brewer has already written you. He understood
your letter to say that you wanted one for yourself
and each of the children, and thinking you had only
two children he sent you three of each.

When he received my order to send five of
each he was stymied because you said to not write the
check for more than twenty-five dollars. He saw
immediately that there were more photographs than you knew
about and that five of each would greatly exceed your
expected expenditure. Three of each cost you eighteen
dollars and there are still more to come. I understand
under these circumstances he has asked you to determine
again whether you want two more of each one regardless
of cost, or to place the order for what you do want.

We are all greatly concerned about the
autographed portraits of Kissinger and Moran. I received
your letter stating that you were sending them, but so
far as any of us know they were never received. We had,
meanwhile, sent to these men for pictures and Mr. Brewer
received one from each man. These were the portraits which
we used and which portraits were not autographed. We still
have them but none of us have ever seen the portraits
which you intended to send and which they had autographed.
Mr. Brewer has the feeling that you sent them to a
photographer to have copies made from them and that you
probably did not get them back, but I do not recall his reason
for thinking this. I am inclined to believe that you sent
them to us but that they were lost in the mail. No one
here has ever seen them so far as we can find out. We are
greatly distressed about this and hope you do not lose
them.

Harriet did receive “Intermezzo” but was not
sure who had sent it and in the confusion failed to write.
She is very appreciative of it and you will be hearing
from her.

Everything is going along and I am hoping somehow
to get away and visit Rochester in the middle of the
winter. I will be conjuring up some proposed dates
pretty soon and then I will check with you.
Our love to Mary and the children.
div1.closer:
Fraternally yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
